subject: Re: What happened to o?
msgSnippet: ... and ... I suppose I should have guess that, huh? Well, personally, I like the idea of the extra vowel, one because I have a tendency to pronounce it (or
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Need the world be informed?"
<teraiten@h...> wrote:
> The dictionary has been generated with the CMU phonetic dictionary,
> wich is based on American pronunciation. In this pronunciation, y
and
> o are considered one sound.
>
> I know of no British-English pronunciation dictionary. If anyone
> knows, please tell!

I suppose I should have guess that, huh?

Well, personally, I like the idea of the extra vowel, one because I
have a tendency to pronounce it (or something close to it. Maybe.)
when I'm nervous or excited (too much British Comedy, I guess), and
two, because I can imagine it occasionally making words easier to
recognize when spelled (IE, the same reason 'r' is always spelled out
in Quickscript.)

I think I may pay the £16.95 for Cambridge's Pronouncing Dictionary.

http://titles.cambridge.org/catalogue.asp?isbn=0521017122

Although, if any one's feeling philanthropic, Cambridge will sell you
its pronouncing dictionary database in SGML form for a paltry £500.
